cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 4:7

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: The Employee's Post-Employment Duty of Confidentiality

para.paratext: The standard test used by the courts to determine whether a former employee has breached the duty of confidentiality was set forth in the leading English case of Amber Size and Chemical Co. v. Menzel:

In my view, after giving the authorities the best attention I can, the law stands thus:—The Court will restrain an ex-servant from publishing or divulging that which has been communicated to him in confidence or under a contract by him, express or implied, not to do so: Morison v. Moat [9 Hare 241], and generally from making an improper use of information obtained in the course of confidential employment: Tuck & Sons v. Priester [19 Q.B.D. 629], and, further, from using to his late master's detriment information and knowledge surreptitiously obtained from him during his, the servant's, employment: Robb v. Green [[1895] 2 Q.B. 1, 315].
In applying these principles I have to answer four questions of fact:—
First, Did the plaintiffs in fact possess and exercise a secret process?
Secondly, Did the defendant during the course of his employment know that this process was secret?
Thirdly, Did the defendant acquire knowledge during his employment of that secret or a material part thereof?
Fourthly, Has he since leaving the plaintiff's employ made an improper use of the knowledge so acquired by him?[1]

The Canadian courts have expressly adopted this fourfold test set forth in Amber Size. The Ontario Court of Appeal decision in International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar,[2] is a key case in which it was held that the courts will restrain a former employee from:
publishing or divulging that which was communicated in confidence or under an express or implied contract not to divulge;
generally making an improper use of information obtained in the course of confidential employment; and
using, to the former employer's detriment, information and knowledge secretly obtained during employment.

The plaintiff in Claim Analytics Inc. v. Polon[3] was granted an interim and interlocutory injunction against the defendants to prevent the disclosure of confidential information, being the “Diagnosis Database”, a predictive model that the plaintiff used in its core business to serve a narrow area of demand within the insurance market.[4]

The plaintiff corporation was founded by the defendant, Jonathan Polon and Senensky. In March, 2014, after Senensky triggered a buy/sell provision in the Shareholders Agreement entered into by their respective shareholder corporations, Polon sold his interest in the plaintiff to Senensky and left Claim Analytics.[5]

The Diagnosis Database was a key part of the plaintiff's confidential information. In addition to creating and offering predictive models in respect of long-term and short-term disability claim scoring, another core part of the plaintiff's business was to provide services in relation to “Benchmarking Studies”, which provide a claim recovery comparison to various insurers. The plaintiff and Munich Re co-sponsored two Benchmarking Studies in relation to group long-term disability claims experience for Canadian insurers in 2011 and 2014. The plaintiff and Munich Re had discussed co-sponsorship of a new study to take place in 2016 and had planned to offer it to the Canadian insurers who participated in the previous study and to others. However, when the plaintiff insisted upon looking for some kind of guaranteed revenue from Munich Re, Munich Re advised the plaintiff that it was not acceptable and minimum revenues did not fit with Munich Re's objectives. Munich Re then sought out Polon and agreed to conduct its 2016 Benchmarking Study with him rather than with the plaintiff, mainly because Polon was willing to do the study for the same financial structure as had been charged in the past.[6]

The dispute centered around the confidentiality of the concept and technique to create a Diagnosis Database. Polon submitted that the predictive models were unique 10 years ago but that is no longer the case. He stated that all material confidential information and trade secrets had already been disclosed into the public domain by the plaintiff itself. This included both a) information disseminated by the plaintiff in papers, articles and presentations as well as b) concepts developed by persons with no affiliation to the plaintiff inclusive of works published in text books, scholarly articles and conveyed to the public during presentations. Accordingly, qualified individuals are capable of building their own predictive models, including insurance claim scoring.[7]

However, the motions judge observed with respect to the Diagnosis Database that (a) the Confidential Information related to specific novel methods, processes and compilations of information created and developed by the plaintiff; (b) the plaintiff had consistently treated this information as confidential: (i) although the general concept has been disclosed outside of the business, important elements of the Diagnosis Database remained secret; (ii) the plaintiff was a closely-knit business with few employees; (iii) the plaintiff required third parties, employees, and even its shareholders to agree to the confidentiality of its information; (iv) the Diagnosis Database represented an important data transformation which distinguished the plaintiff's predictive models; (v) the Diagnosis Database had been evolving and growing since 2003; (vi) Without specific knowledge of the seven variables for each of the diagnosis codes, the manner in which scores were assigned to the variables, and particularly the eighth element of the Diagnosis Database, it could not be easily duplicated. The plaintiff had mapped each medical diagnosis it encountered in its customers' data into a set of variables which were rated 0 or 1 to 10. As of March 2014, there were seven variables scored for each of the hundreds of diagnosis codes. Of the seven variables, five had been disclosed in presentations or academic papers. Two of the variables remained confidential.[8]

The motions judge observed that even when all of the information becomes public, if an ex-employee is able, by information provided by or developed for the previous employer to gain an advantage that he or she would not have had, it would provide a spring board for an unfair advantage over others. What is really being protected in situations of this nature is the original process of mind. The protection is enforced against persons who wish to use the confidential information without spending time, trouble and expense of going through the same process to prevent them from getting an unfair start. In any event, the full Diagnosis Database had not been disclosed publicly and the plaintiff had taken protective measures to ensure its confidentiality. A misappropriation of trade secrets by a former employee will give rise to liability for which there is injunctive relief. There was sufficient evidence to establish that there was a serious issue to be tried with respect to the imminent threat of breach of confidence and fiduciary duty by Polon.[9]
In Seyedi v. Nexen Inc.,[10] the following issue was raised on this appeal: (b) Was Seyedi prohibited from taking information belonging to Nexen upon departure?[11]

The appellant was an experienced foreign-trained engineer who participated in the Alberta Human Services' program to provide him with Canadian engineering experience. The program was administered by the Calgary Catholic Immigration Society. A letter of understanding was entered into between CCIS, Seyedi and the Respondent Nexen pursuant to which Seyedi served a three-month unpaid practicum with Nexen. At the conclusion of that practicum, Nexen did not offer employment to Seyedi as he had hoped. He then sued Nexen claiming misappropriation of certain intellectual property he had provided to it, aimed at solving a certain environmental problem. Nexen counterclaimed, asserting that Seyedi had misappropriated confidential information when he departed at the end of his practicum.[12]

Nexen called no evidence at trial. Seyedi called, in addition to testifying himself, two witnesses, both Nexen employees, notwithstanding the trial judge's repeated warnings about the risks of calling witnesses allied with Nexen as part of his own case. Both of these witnesses denied that Nexen used his Plan at any time. It had identified and adopted another approach to solving the problem to which the Plan was directed. Seyedi unsuccessfully attempted to convince the judge otherwise, although he led no other direct evidence on this point. Seyedi admitted to having no personal knowledge to the contrary during his own testimony, also admitting that, upon his departure from Nexen, he took Nexen documents without consent.[13]

The trial judge awarded Nexen judgment on the counterclaim, based on evidence including Seyedi's admission that he had taken technical engineering reports and analysis, emails and other documents from Nexen upon his departure. This was a violation of his obligation to keep all information learned while at Nexen confidential. As a result, she ordered Seyedi to return or destroy all information that he had taken.[14]

Seyedi argued that this did not amount to misappropriation of confidential information for the following reasons: he did not believe what he took was confidential as it was not marked “confidential”; he had not signed a non-disclosure agreement with Nexen; Nexen was unreasonable in claiming that all its documentation and information was confidential unless made public; no harm was done as he had shown this information to no one post-departure; and, he had a duty to take documents showing Nexen was unnecessarily polluting the environment to show regulators. He did not testify, however, that he showed any of this information to any regulator.[15]

The trial judge found that Seyedi's relationship with Nexen was akin to that of employer-employee and, as such, he had a duty as an employee not to disclose confidential employer information. It was not necessary to now determine whether the obligations of an employee extend to unpaid interns because the obligation not to misappropriate confidential material is not limited to employees and did, in these circumstances, extend to Seyedi.[16]

While Seyedi disputed Nexen's claims that he signed a confidentiality agreement with it, and the trial judge made no express finding on this point, obligations of confidence can exist without such a signed agreement or a contract of employment. The obligation not to disclose confidential information arises from the second branch of the Lac Minerals test, in relation to any information that “was communicated in confidence” whether or not the party to whom it was communicated was employed by the party doing the communication. Whether information is communicated in confidence or not is determined by applying a “reasonable man” test, as described in Lac Minerals at 612-613, 636, applying the statements of Megarry J in Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1968] F.S.R. 415 (Eng. Ch. Div.) at 419 at 420-421:

It seems to me that if the circumstances are such that any reasonable man standing in the shoes of the recipient of the information would have realized that upon reasonable grounds the information was being given to him in confidence, then this should suffice to impose upon him the equitable obligation of confidence. In particular, where information of commercial or industrial value is given on a business-like basis and with some avowed common object in mind … I would regard the recipient as carrying a heavy burden if he seeks to repel a contention that he was bound by an obligation of confidence …[17]

Applying this test, Seyedi was under an obligation not to take confidential information, as any reasonable person in his position would have realized that the information was given to him in confidence. The evidence was uncontroverted on this point: Seyedi had attended a workshop where he was told that all business records and information imparted to him during his practicum were confidential. Thus, the trial judge was correct in reaching her conclusion that Mr. Seyedi was prohibited from taking information belonging to Nexen upon departure, whether or not he was otherwise bound by the same obligations as an employee.[18]

A motion for an order requiring the defendant Mew to answer certain questions he refused to answer on his examination for discovery was granted in Aon Reed Stenhouse Inc. v. Marsh Canada Ltd.[19] The plaintiff and the defendant Marsh were two of the world's leading providers of risk management and insurance brokerage services. The plaintiff and Marsh were direct competitors in a very competitive business. The defendants Mew and Parsons were both long-time senior employees of the plaintiff. During the course of their employment with the plaintiff they were both involved in providing services to one of the plaintiff's significant clients, Fairmont. In December, 2009, Mew and Parsons left the plaintiff and joined Marsh. On January 21, 2010, Fairmont advised the plaintiff that it was moving its business to Marsh. The plaintiff alleged that Mew and Parsons, prior to their departure from their employment with the plaintiff, solicited Fairmont's business on behalf of Marsh, contrary to their contractual and other legal obligations to the plaintiff. Moreover, the plaintiff alleged that Mew and Parsons did so by using confidential and proprietary information belonging to the plaintiff. Finally, the plaintiff alleged that Mew and Parsons continued to misuse such confidential and proprietary information after joining Marsh, in connection with providing ongoing insurance and risk management services to Fairmont.[20]

The questions refused on Mew's examination related to the plaintiff's request that Mew provide certain information and documents relating to his involvement with Fairmont on behalf of Marsh between January 21, 2010 and December, 2010. The plaintiff argued that those questions and documents were relevant to its claim against Mew for breach of confidence. Specifically, the plaintiff alleged that during this time period, Mew provided services to Fairmont on behalf of Marsh by, in part, using confidential information belonging to the plaintiff. Mew argued that there was simply no evidence that he took any confidential information with him when he left his employment with the plaintiff. Indeed, he explicitly denied taking any such information with him. He did admit that in providing services to Fairmont on behalf of Marsh he would have applied his skills and abilities derived from his 30 years of experience in the industry.[21]

The court concluded that the plaintiff's requests did not constitute a fishing expedition. First, the allegations of misuse of confidential information were clearly and specifically pleaded in the statement of claim. Moreover, there existed certain circumstantial evidence that provided at least some support to these allegations. Mew was a long-term and senior employee of the plaintiff who admitted that he had access to confidential information concerning Fairmont when he was employed by the plaintiff. It was only one month after Mew and Parsons left the plaintiff and joined Marsh that Fairmont announced that it was taking its business from the plaintiff to Marsh. Mew then began immediately working on the Fairmont account, in apparent breach of the terms of the non-competition provisions of his employment agreements with the plaintiff. None of this meant that Mew actually misused, or even possessed, confidential information belonging to the plaintiff. That, however, was a matter for the trial judge to decide. The plaintiff's line of inquiry was not overly broad or speculative. The plaintiff's allegations of misuse of confidential information rose to the level of relevance.[22]

The plaintiff was not asking the court to make a finding of fact based on a presumption that Mew, in providing services to Fairmont, must have misused confidential information or the proprietary work product of the plaintiff. The plaintiff was simply seeking information and documents relevant to its claim for breach of confidence and there existed at least some evidence to support those allegations.[23]
Orders for injunctive relief have issued permitting a third party forensic inspector to attend at the offices of the defendant to ensure confidential information is removed.[24]

In Firm Capital Corp. v. Moncada,[25] the Plaintiffs brought a motion for an urgent order that the Defendant return immediately the confidential information that she had in her possession related to the Plaintiff corporations. The Defendant was an employee of Firm Capital Corporation for more than 20 years. She held the position of Vice President of Finance and Accounting when she was terminated on May 28, 2014. Moncada in her position received and had access to confidential information about the Firm Capital Parties and the principal, Dadouch. Moncada had confidential information related to the Plaintiffs on her personal computer. The Plaintiffs alleged that Moncada stole in excess of $400,000 from the companies during the course of her employment. Dadouch was engaged in matrimonial litigation with his former wife who alleged that she met with Moncada and was provided with information concerning the financial affairs of Dadouch, in particular, information about assets that Dadouch has not disclosed in the matrimonial proceedings. The wife obtained an order in the matrimonial proceedings that Moncada attend for questioning.[26]

Counsel agreed that Deloitte would copy the confidential information from Moncada's computer and thereafter delete it. They also agree that this would be done under the supervision of an Independent Supervising Solicitor. The issues that the parties did not agree on was whether the IT expert from Deloitte's should take an image of Moncada's hard drive from her computer for preservation at the time the confidential documents are copied and deleted and whether Moncada ought to be obligated to give a sworn affirmation that what had been produced constitutes all confidential documentation in her possession. The motion judge concluded that both issues required affirmative answers. The relief sought by the Plaintiffs today did not amount to an Anton Pillar order. Without question, there are significant credibility issues in both this action and the matrimonial litigation. Moncada had documentation in her possession that is confidential that arose from her employment with the Firm Capital Parties. She admits meeting with the wife of the principal but denied providing confidential information about the businesses to her as asserted.[27]

The Plaintiffs did not seek production of Moncada's hard drive, including all sorts of personal documentation. What was being requested was that an image of the hard drive be made at the time the confidential documentation is obtained and deleted, to be done by an independent third party. It was in the interests of all parties that an order issue preserving the contents of the hard drive of Moncada's computer. No prejudice or intrusion to Moncada's privacy would result from this order. Rather, it would obviate potential problems down the road if there was a concern that there was other data that was relevant on her computer which was not produced as part of the confidential information. This was very different from an order requiring production of the contents of Moncada's hard drive of her computer.[28]

Numerous requests through counsel were made of Moncada to return all confidential Firm Capital documents and records. The documents were not returned and there was no explanation for her failure to do so. The motion judge made no finding concerning whether or not the confidential information was truly confidential. However, it was not up to Moncada to make that determination. An order requiring Moncada to confirm she had provided all of the confidential information was no different than requiring a party to swear an Affidavit of Documents.[29]

Amber Size and Chemical Co. v. Menzel, [1913] 2 Ch. 239, at pp. 244-5. In the proper circumstances, the courts will prevent future dissemination of information even though there has yet to be an actual “improper use”. See also Consolidated Textiles Ltd. v. Central Dynamics Ltd., [1974] 2 F.C. 814 at p. 827, 18 C.P.R. (2d) 1 (T.D.); R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton, [1950] 1 D.L.R. 601 at p. 609, [1950] O.R. 62 (C.A.); PPG Industries Inc. v. Green (1973), 13 C.P.R. (2d) 71 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 75; Cooperheat v. Slater (1973), 13 C.P.R. (2d) 25 (Ont. H.C.J.), at p. 26; Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.), at p. 51.
International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar (1968), 67 D.L.R. (2d) 386, [1968] 1 O.R. 669 (C.A.).
